You're missing a couple of things. First, I'd guess no one knows how much American and European banks and other large investors have locked up in Chinese ghost cities and other terrible investments. Second, we do know that there is a lot of Chinese money invested here and in Europe. Third, China is the biggest growth market for a lot of firms. The loss of that growth will harm stock prices worldwide.

We know some of the Chinese growth is an illusion, but we don't know just how much is real and how much is fake. All of this leads to uncertainty, which is the real cause of all panics. It causes people to stop lending and to hoard assets, particularly in our interconnected economies.

If things unravel quickly, the whole world is going to slump. I do think the Chinese government will continue to do everything it can to prevent a slump, so the effects will be mitigated.

Over the course of several centuries, China has exhibited one consistency: the warlord culture. Disguised by any number of Red facades, it made it through the various (cultural) revolutions as the oriental invisible hand controlling the market.

The warlords are now capitalized as party members (who else?) who dominate economic strata. They, as they always have, will fend for themselves. Central authority is as solid as the Emperor was a century ago, and the events to unfold could be another Boxer Rebellion - except for the absence of foreign targets (the new mandarins will do nicely).

Bohemienne, I am a wildlife biologist by training and practice (and I teach science now) and I think your fears are unfounded. The more I study the philosophy of environmentalism, the more I think end of the world scenarios are simply something about our anxiety about death, and fear of change, and nostalgia for the good old days.

Where I live now, people have their babies very young, in their late teens to early 20s. Many are grandparents in their 30s, including people I teach with at my school. Only 10% of the adult population in my county has been to college, and of those, most are employees of the school district and hospital, and we are outsiders here. Can you imagine that? I think you are envisioning a middle class Utopia that just doesn't exist for most people in the world.

As I see it, I think poverty and human suffering and misery could be alleviated through better regulation and taxation on rich corporations, and with family-wage jobs. You often write about how immigration is going to plug the coming hole in our population, as if immigrants come here as adults only, with no desire for children of their own, no need for FMLA, a family wage job or benefits or security. Many of the students I teach are the children of immigrants, who work in the service sector in a tourist economy, with no health benefits, no system for retirement savings or long-term disability, yet they have children already. It's like you are the one speaking a foreign language.

What a feat of construction we have here: a mere half dozen three-letter entries, few abbreviations, and no junk to be found! I had a smashing time filling in all the little delights in today's grid, my favorite clue being the one for HYMNALS.

Somewhat disappointingly, I ended up erring on three squares, two because of LANA and VIGODA instead of my imagined LARA and VIGOTA (SINE DIE is a new one for me... sounds like the exclamation of a frustrated trig student), and one because of my adherence to AD BRACELET (ID BRACELET didn't register for some reason while solving... in fact, I dismissed the possibility, thinking it sounded too Freudian).

Seeing "stevedore" and "EMBOWERED" in this puzzle was a treat; both of those words were taught to me quite recently, by a marvelous band out of Portland called The Decemberists.

I agree with your skepticism about competitive balance up to a point. The NFL and MLB are clearly more balanced then the NBA, with 10 and 9 different champions, respectively, in the last 15 years, compared to 6 in the NBA. And if we look at the total number of different teams that contended in the final game/series, we get 19 for the NFL, 16 for MLB, and 13 for the NBA.

But realistically, I would say 9 different NBA teams have a chance to win next year: the Clippers, Rockets, Spurs, Thunder, & Warriors in the West, and the Bulls, Heat, Nets, & Pacers in the East. At most 3 of those teams, the Bulls, Heat, & Spurs, are perennial powerhouses, and truthfully, the Bulls haven't dominated since the Jordan era, and the Spurs belie the theory of big-market dominance. So I still think it's fun, and I'll root for the West's contender regardless of the fact that my hometown Nuggets probably can't make it past the 2nd round, at best (and more likely the 1st), this year.

The San Antonio Spurs aren't a major market, yet they've been contending for the last 15 years. OKC has been in the mix the last few years and was a title favorite this year until Patrick Beverly got excited. In the last 15 years or so: Sacramento, Phoenix, Houston, Memphis, Utah, Indiana, Detroit, Orlando, and Portland have all had legitimate chances to win the title, with Detroit taking one.

Sure there are perennial losers and the system isn't perfect, but no sport has achieved the idealistic parity you're espousing - hello Cleveland, Cincinnati, Buffalo, Miami and Detroit of the NFL.

Players often want to play in major market cities because, um, have you been to Los Angeles? The league should do as much as possible to promote and ensure parity, but the NBA isn't as set in stone as people like to say it is. Heck if Dan Gilbert could have fielded a better supporting cast we might be sitting here talking about a dynasty - in Cleveland!

It's hard to get excited about the NBA when knowledgeable sportswriters admit that only a handful of teams at best have a chance of winning a championship in any given year. Why follow a league that has a regular season filled with meaningless games and a two-month playoff season with the winner largely pre-determined?

Maybe I didn't read the right stories, but for years the NBA's soft salary cap was its big open secret. Teams regularly willing to exceed the cap were perennial contenders. Players still have a clear preference for big cities and warm-weather cities, so the unbalanced playing field gets further tilted. And the referees' preferential treatment of superstars makes a bad situation worse. No wonder so many casual observers of the NBA mutter about fixed outcomes, even after Tim Donaghy has faded into obscurity.

The harder salary cap now in place is good; an unyielding salary cap like the NFL's would be better. A salary floor closer to the cap and increased revenue sharing would help. This last idea might be crazy, but why not require teams to play most or all of its active players during a game? A superstar-laden team like the Heat might struggle when its weak bench had to match up against a stronger bench spelling good-but-not-great starters on the other team.

Right now the NBA is not uniformly competitive. It's gaudy, overhyped and star-driven but it's ultimately predictable and boring if your team isn't a favorite for the Finals.

I am wondering if Lewis's model has any application to developed economies, including the U.S., post-2008? It seems to me that the EU and the U.S. are creating pools of surplus labor, including substantial numbers of underemployed. As well, we appear to be seeing a sharper division between large, highly profitable, often multi-national corporations and many smaller, more localized firms.

While the division between larger, profitable corporations and smaller, less-efficient companies does not follow Lewis's agricultural/manufacturing paradigm in emerging markets, it does fit the general paradigm of less-advanced economy alongside a more developed one. In the U.S., for example, we routinely refer to the divisions between the Wall Street economy and the Main Street one.

Does Lewis's model have any explanatory power with respect to dual economies in the developed world?
